content.body: "with" sometimes appears in golfing?
I mean, I imagine it appears in many contexts, being a common English word.
Code golf
I find it most odd that HTTP gurus oppose the use of POST for ping on safety grounds
what are the safety grounds?
if anyone ever understand the objection, please let me know, so i can fix it
can ping produce POSTs that can't be produced by posting a form?
othermaciej: see Roy's Change Proposal
i've tried many times to understand the objection, but not been able to
avoids summarizing in order to avoid missummarizing
hsivonen: ah, when you say "safety grounds" you just mean the official HTTP classification of what methods are labeled "safe"
othermaciej: yes
I wonder if it is a relevant consideration that a submit button can be styled to look just like a link
(let alone the fact that a POST can be issued programmatically from an onclick handler)
http://damowmow.com/playground/demos/http/002/ is relevant
what Content-Type does the ping post use?
note that the test.html file on that page has no script
yet it can trick people (even highly experienced http experts) into causing POSTs to be submitted
clever, that one doesn't even require form controls to be stylable
othermaciej: It doesn't seem that anything is a relevant consideration except the notion that POST is unsafe
i guess if POST is unsafe and POST is part of HTTP that means HTTP is unsafe!
Only in browsers, because browsers never do anything right
Is there a wrapping element for HTML 5? I need a container of all my elements to set a side width, should I just use a div?
yes
<div> is that element
Thanks
jgraham: yt?
gsnedders: Yes
How many times does someone have to repeat obvious falsehoods and be corrected before you assume bad faith?
6 or 7
http://qdb.us/295884
http://www.android.com/ has a <link rel="stylesheet" href="//google.com/css/inlay.css">
I wonder if that href type is going to catch on
Dashiva: I expect redirect from http to https catch on first
How does that look?
Dashiva: just a 301 respons with an https URL in the Location header
hsivonen: How does the server know to offer a redirect to an HTTPS alternative? Referer header?
Dashiva: Slashdot has used that style for ages
webben: by seeing which port was used for the request
wishes the chairs would point out to Shelley that the HTML WG charter covers application in addition to documents
hsivonen: But if you serve up HTML response over SSL, but link to a resource with http:// won't it use port 80 when requesting that resource?
s/it/the UA/
webben: I meant not serving up HTML as http but redirecting to https at that point
hey all, re: abbr/acronym, is there a way now for authors to indicate whether the term should be read as a word (like FUD) or as initials (like CIA)? Or is that up to AT?
boblet: it's up to the AT, as it has always been
zcorpan: ok, thanks. I was under the impression that historically that was the distinction between abbr/acronym. good to know
As far as I'm aware it should be the same as for non-marked-up abbreviations, and the same as for all non-abbreviated collections of characters too
i.e. it's the AT's job to work out how to read text

another random question; it’s fine to have an id and a class with the same name, right? Spec doesn’t forbid it (id value unique amongst all ids in subtree), but wondering if eg browser bug or other gotcha
it's fine
thanks zcorpan
so anyone's got any comments on the xml-stylesheet draft?
Ooh, Chrome has neat UI for untrusted SSL certs: it writes "https" in red, but has a little slash through it too.
Very noticeable.
